issues.title: Add text about endorsements for layers other than the bottom
issues.author: dthaler

issues.title: Requested feedback
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
- The following is NOT always applicable: 
> where actual state has a single value per claim per component applying to one device at one point in time, reference state has a set of values per claim per component (§2)

It may very well be the case that there is only one Reference Value per Claim per component (e.g., _MRENCLAVE_ in SGX).

- The following is NOT always the case: 
> Actual state: Evidence, Endorsements, Attestation Results (§2.1)

As a counterexample, _CPUSVN_ inside PCK cert (Endorsement) may be older than the one in Evidence (QE Report Body). 

- I think the draft currently focuses on a very specific case rather than the goal stated in the abstract: 
> explains the purpose and role of Endorsements

One of the major purposes of Endorsements is to provide identity endorsement, which is never discussed in the draft. 

- Clarify "group of claims" vs. "set of claims" (e.g., as used in §2)

- Clarify the definition of "Claim" and explain: 
> for our purposes we will treat such a list as a single unit (§2)

For example, I am thinking about _attributes_ and _Security Version Numbers_ in SGX/TDX. For instance, SGX TCB Security Version Number (SVN) has 16 components, so would each component be treated as a Claim, or would the SVN be treated as a single unit?

- Clarify "reference values" vs. "Reference Values"

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
> * The following is NOT always applicable:
> 
> > where actual state has a single value per claim per component applying to one device at one point in time, reference state has a set of values per claim per component (§2)
> 
> It may very well be the case that there is only one Reference Value per Claim per component (e.g., _MRENCLAVE_ in SGX).

There is no contradiction.  A single-value can still be represented as a set of size one in such a case.

> * The following is NOT always the case:
> 
> > Actual state: Evidence, Endorsements, Attestation Results (§2.1)
> 
> As a counterexample, _CPUSVN_ inside PCK cert (Endorsement) may be older than the one in Evidence (QE Report Body).

I don't understand the relevance of your statement to the quoted text. Please clarify your feedback.
I suspect the "Conditionally Endorsed Values" section will be the answer to your question.

> * I think the draft currently focuses on a very specific case rather than the goal stated in the abstract:
> 
> > explains the purpose and role of Endorsements
> 
> One of the major purposes of Endorsements is to provide identity endorsement, which is never discussed in the draft.

Draft-02 added section 4 "Endorsing Identity".

> * Clarify "group of claims" vs. "set of claims" (e.g., as used in §2)

"set of claims" is used synonymously with "claimset" in other documents, where Evidence can have multiple claimsets, one per component.  I'm using "group of claims" to refer to a set of claimsets.  Will clarify.

> * Clarify the definition of "Claim" and explain:
> 
> > for our purposes we will treat such a list as a single unit (§2)
> 
> For example, I am thinking about _attributes_ and _Security Version Numbers_ in SGX/TDX. For instance, SGX TCB Security Version Number (SVN) has 16 components, so would each component be treated as a Claim, or would the SVN be treated as a single unit?

The hardware is a component, and has multiple claims of which SVN might be one unit if the EAT profile (or CORIM or whatever else) defined it as such.

> * Clarify "reference values" vs. "Reference Values"

Should be the latter for consistency.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
> > * The following is NOT always applicable:
> > 
> > > where actual state has a single value per claim per component applying to one device at one point in time, reference state has a set of values per claim per component (§2)
> > 
> > 
> > It may very well be the case that there is only one Reference Value per Claim per component (e.g., _MRENCLAVE_ in SGX).
> 
> There is no contradiction. A single-value can still be represented as a set of size one in such a case.
> 

If both actual state and reference state can be represented as sets, then the distinction between actual state and reference state in the draft is very weak. The distinction should be more precisely clarified. 
> > * The following is NOT always the case:
> > 
> > > Actual state: Evidence, Endorsements, Attestation Results (§2.1)
> > 
> > 
> > As a counterexample, _CPUSVN_ inside PCK cert (Endorsement) may be older than the one in Evidence (QE Report Body).
> 
> I don't understand the relevance of your statement to the quoted text. Please clarify your feedback. I suspect the "Conditionally Endorsed Values" section will be the answer to your question.
> 

Just to clarify, this was not supposed to be a question. This was supposed to be a counter-example that as opposed to what the draft (e.g., quoted text) says, Endorsements may not always represent actual state. 
> > * I think the draft currently focuses on a very specific case rather than the goal stated in the abstract:
> > 
> > > explains the purpose and role of Endorsements
> > 
> > 
> > One of the major purposes of Endorsements is to provide identity endorsement, which is never discussed in the draft.
> 
> Draft-02 added section 4 "Endorsing Identity".
> 

Thanks, I was reviewing draft-01. I will have a look. 
> > * Clarify "group of claims" vs. "set of claims" (e.g., as used in §2)
> 
> "set of claims" is used synonymously with "claimset" in other documents, where Evidence can have multiple claimsets, one per component. I'm using "group of claims" to refer to a set of claimsets. Will clarify.
> 

I hope to see this question clarified: Is one "component" representing precisely one Target Environment? I think that will precisely distinguish "set of claims"/"claimset" and "group of claims" 
> > * Clarify the definition of "Claim" and explain:
> > 
> > > for our purposes we will treat such a list as a single unit (§2)
> > 
> > 
> > For example, I am thinking about _attributes_ and _Security Version Numbers_ in SGX/TDX. For instance, SGX TCB Security Version Number (SVN) has 16 components, so would each component be treated as a Claim, or would the SVN be treated as a single unit?
> 
> The hardware is a component, and has multiple claims of which SVN might be one unit if the EAT profile (or CORIM or whatever else) defined it as such.
> 

This is very ambiguous to me. The definition of Claim that is used in the draft should be independent of EAT profile/CORIM.

issues.title: ability to constrain which components an endorser can endorse
issues.author: dthaler
issues.body:
Multiple Endorsements should talk about this concept and draft -02 doesn't.
Discussed at IETF 117.

Kathleen Moriarty mentioned same concept is in attestation sets draft.

Henk Birkholz mentioned that corim 3.1.4.1.1 refers to multiple environments, for same reason.

issues.title: key material for attestation
issues.author: dthaler
issues.body: In the IEFT 117 meeting, Laurence suggested not using the word "identity" but rather "key material for verifying evidence" or "attestation keys".  He suggested there might be like 3 pages of stuff to talk about here.   I asked if there were volunteers to contribute such text and the recording shows that two people raised their hands (Thomas Hardjono was one, and I think the other might have been Henk).

comments.body:
> Sorry folks, [this](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/rats-endorsements/commit/376bc8dd4760bc11a65dd13b0915837d5c05dc04) was merged on error. I meant to create a PR but G-H tricked me somehow 😭

comments.body: My bad, Thomas Fossati is already a co-author.  I was confused since github didn't automatically add you as a reviewer.  I meant add folks to CODEOWNERS not the draft itself.  Expect a PR shortly.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
Here's a start. Having trouble with cloning and building, so no PR yet, but wanted to share before the meeting.



A RATS verifier receives evidence from an attester that must be considered untrusted until established otherwise. This trust is established using cryptography. Typically, the attester will sign a nonce with a private key it possesses and the verifier will verify it with a public key it possesses. While this is typical, cryptography other than public key may also be used.

Since it is not possible to establish trust in an attester without cryptography, the verifier must have a verification key for each attester.  The verification key comes to the verifier in an endorsement from an endorser.

No particularly algorithm or cryptographic protocol is assumed for the verification of the attester. The verification key could be a symmetric key, a public key or something more sophisticated. Thus there is no assumption about the type of verification key in the endorsement.

(In theory the verification key could also come in reference values or appraisal policy, the other inputs to the verifier, but that would not line up with the descriptions in the RATS architecture).

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
Thanks @laurencelundblade

There is some wordsmithing I would do to your text but it's a valuable start that we can use.  Thanks for posting this!

issues.title: Section 2.1 comparison rules and appraisal policy
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
Section 2.1 describes appraisal policy as the source of comparison rules for relating actual state with reference (possible) state. However, there are significant comparison dynamics that can occur independent of appraisal policy. For example, a verifier can assume exact match semantics given the reference values are identical to the evidence values. No appraisal policy is required to instruct a verifier to apply exact match semantics.

Additionally, a profile such as https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-cds-rats-intel-corim-profile/ defines Reference Values that define actual value must be in the set of allowed Reference Values and actual value must be in a range where two Reference Values are the min and max.

This suggests that the RVP has insight on how best a verifier should apply matching rules. 

The current text seems to ignore this important aspect.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: What Section 2.1 of rats-endorsements says agrees with Section 8.5 of the architecture.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> What Section 2.1 of rats-endorsements says agrees with Section 8.5 of the architecture.

I'm not following. Did I mention 8.5 of RATS Arch?

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
I am saying that §2.1 or rats-endorsements is currently per §8.5 of RFC9334.

If we want to say something different here we need to:
1. Present the proposal to the WG and get consensus;
2. Mark rats-endorsement as "Update: 9334".

(Note that 2. may already be the case.)

issues.title: Section 3 seems garbled
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
Section 3 seems garbled. Paragraphs 1 and 3 describe reference values interactions (possible states) in a section on actual (endorsed) states.  These should probably be removed from section 3. 

Paragraph 2 seems to give attention to immutable vs. immutable unnecessarily. It bans use of conditionally endorsed values that are immutable. But it is reasonable for an AE to have a serial# that is asserted by one AE while another AE asserts, say a model#. It isn't wrong if an endorsement asserts that a model# is X conditional on a serial# Y. 

Paragraph 2 uses an example that isn't that intuitive as it assumes / asserts that CPU may support different features based on (mutable) firmware. This seems like an obscure example since there is no consistency across the industry regarding whether a CPU vendor's endorsement will differ based on which firmware happens to be loaded. Hence, it isn't providing intuition about the property of immutableness as it pertains to conditional endorsement.

The fourth paragraph seems to derive from the previous 3 but these all have issues, so it is unclear what property is derived. Paragraph 4 simply seems to weigh trade-offs without specifically stating the conditions being compared.

The fifth paragraph describes the relationship between conditional endorsements and policies. But there is no such thing as appraisal policy for endorsements. Hence, it is unclear what point the author is making. 

In toto, section 3 should describe the concept of conditional endorsement as the idea that a second endorsement state may be entered (true) conditional on a first endorsement state being true. 

For example, if an AE has the serial#_X, then the CC evaluation is EAL4+. 

Appraisal policy for AR might determine whether or not CC evaluation claims are relevant. But appraisal policy would (should) not negate an endorsement claim.

issues.title: Section 4 readability
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
I find section 4 difficult to read. The heading "Endorsing Evidence Provenance" is not an intuitive concept. The authors must explain what it means first. 

The first paragraph seems to describe that Evidence should be authenticated. This could be stated more plainly. 

The second paragraph seems to make the same statement, but in a contra indicated way. There is a DICE example in Section 2, that could be referenced as it seems to describe layering. But it isn't clear how paragraph 2 (section 4) pertains to "provenance" or "endorsement". 

For example: "Such a certificate need not be stored by the Verifier when the Endorsement can be resolved on demand or passed to the Verifier along with the Evidence"
The concept of "Endorsement resolution" is not described in the I-D. The reader is assumed to know what this entails. It's relevance to "provenance" is not obvious.
 
I believe the first sentence of the 3rd paragraph is actually incorrect:
"No particular algorithm or cryptographic protocol is assumed for the verification of the Attester."
A verifier must implement the algorithm/protocol that authenticates the Attester / AE otherwise the integrity of the evidence is suspect. 

"Evidence typically contains an identifier for the Attester (e.g., [[I-D.ietf-rats-eat](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-rats-endorsements-01.html#I-D.ietf-rats-eat)] ueid) in a claim, sometimes termed an "identity claim", that can be used by the Verifier to look up its verification key for the Attester."
The 4th paragraph is not typical as Evidence often describes a class of devices rather than a specific instance of a device. 
Instead, it is typical for a lead Attester to have authentication credentials that identifies an instance of a device. However, this is also is contradicted by I-D:daa-attestation where a group key maintains the class nature of evidence while also authenticating the evidence. 

The fifth paragraph seems to take a circumlocutions approach to saying that Evidence must be authenticated (restating what the first paragraph is saying) and that Evidence authentication should be the first step before applying other appraisal steps. Maybe this could be said more directly?

The last paragraph seems to be summarizing the steps that a verifier might follow, but seems out of place in a section on evidence provenance. 

It is still unclear to me if the goal of the section is to assert that Evidence provenance means Evidence should be authenticated, if this is giving general (cherry picked) advice to verifiers, or if this is aimed at Endorsers who may need to do something (???) in order to ensure Endorsements have "provenance" (e.g., sign endorsement claims?).

Maybe a different approach would be to explain that AE's have attestation keys that authenticate evidence and that provenance of attestation keys is needed to build trust in the AEs? This is what the PKIX  Consortium refers to as "key attestation". Maybe the authors are saying that AEs' attestation keys should be backed by key attestation?

issues.title: Figure 2 suggestions for readability
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
Figure 2 describes the concept that endorsements can provide additional claims to those provided by evidence. The figure uses "claimset" to refer to the set of claims that are asserted by a particular entity (Attester, Hardware Endorseer, etc.). However, it isn't clear in the diagram that the "Hardware claimset" asserted by the Attester is different from the "hardware claimset" asserted by the Hardware Endorser. A simple terminology change could improve this. For example, the Hardware Endorser might assert "Additional Hardware Claims" while the Attester asserts "Hardware Claims". The Hardware "claimset" = "Hardware Claims" + "Additional Hardware Claims". 

Section 5 states:
"The binding between Target Environment and Endorser might be part of the Appraisal Policy for Evidence"
This seems incorrect as the binding between Endorsements claims and Evidence claims is based on the matching condition found in the Endorsement claims. 

I'm confused by "or might be specified as part of the Evidence itself, or some combination of the two"
because it isn't clear what the connection is between Evidence and Appraisal policy for Evidence that defines a binding between a TE and an Endorser. Use of the term "binding" seems overloaded with other uses within the same document.  Wouldn't the TE be identified by its class / instance name? Wouldn't the Endorser and Attester developers have to agree on these names?

issues.title: Section 6.2 comments
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
Section 6.2 first paragraph:
"We currently assume that Reference Value Providers and Endorsers typically provide the same information"
This sentence seems to contradict what is stated above since RVPs provide "reference" or "possible" state claimsets while Endorsers provide "actual" state claimsets.

This line: "clients ... are generally on devices that are not constrained nodes"
is not commonly agreed upon as there are many cases of embedded verifiers, BMCs and so forth. The conclusion that scalability of verifiers "is not a significant concern" to RATS is not true or that it is not "typical". 

The following paragraph seems to reinforce my point. 

This may be writing style. But the first paragraph should introduce what will be described in subsequent paragraphs, rather than contradict them.

The last two paragraphs seem more focused on complexity than scalability. Maybe they belong in section 6.1? BTW: If this is intended as a security considerations section it shouldn't be a subsection heading. Othewise, this section seems to be about complexity hence it's heading might be more reflective of this.

Section 6 isn't so much about formats as it is about complexity and scalability.  It is possible to use different formats to encode simple things or a single format to encode complex things.

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body: @thomas-fossati what do you think?

pulls.title: Add notion of identity endorsements
pulls.author: dthaler
pulls.body:
Addresses https://github.com/dthaler/rats-endorsements-old/issues/2

However I don't think they're really another type of endorsement per se, use is really up to the Appraisal Policy for Evidence.

reviews.author: OR13
reviews.body:
This is possible a bit off topic, but I have been considering the case for SCITT and KT,  where the COSE payload is a key content type (jwk+json, or cose-key) and the header contains claims that bind that key to an identifier, for example `email` or `website`... 

It's nice be able to dedicate the entire payload to a content type, but this leaves only headers to establish relationships.

For example SCITT has feeds, which would support this... You could have a feed that only supports endorsed keys, from certain parties and for certain purposes, but with support for multiple key content types.

pulls.title: Incorporate key material text suggestions from Laurence
pulls.author: dthaler
pulls.body:
This PR incorporates suggestions from @laurencelundblade 

Fixes #7

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Dave, thanks for turning my crude first pass into a PR.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
@dthaler @henkbirkholz @laurencelundblade:

The draft is going to expire soon (2024-06-03).

There are a few remaining review comments that need to be addressed before we can wrap this up.

Can you please try and have a look to see what's missing / what needs changing in your view?

It'd be great if we could reach a consensus in the next few days as this is the only PR we need to merge before we publish an update and ask WGLC on the document.

comments.author: dthaler
comments.body:
Merging after sufficient time has passed after saying when I would merge this unless I heard objections.
I will submit a new draft version, and any further comments can be dealt with in a new PR if needed.

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: good stuff, thanks.  I have left a few comments and suggestions inline.

comments.body:
```suggestion
with a private key that the Attesting Environment possesses and the Verifier will verify
```

one _"cryptographically"_ can probably be removed without loss of information, e.g.:

```suggestion
cryptographically verify that the Evidence
has been generated by the Attester that has the key material associated
```

extra comma (not in the scope of this PR, but since we in the area)

```suggestion
This document treats identity claims as with any other claims but allows
```

slight streamlining

```suggestion
A Verifier receives Evidence from an Attester that must be considered untrusted
until verified through cryptography. Typically,
```

The sentence _"[t]he Verifier must have a verification key for each Attester."_ may give the impression that a Verifier must be provisioned with the key that verifies the Attester's signature.  In reality, the requirement is less stringent: it is sufficient that the Verifier is given enough information to trust the verification key (e.g., via one or more CA certs) rather than to _"have"_ such verification key.  I.e., the actual key could be in-band with Evidence as long as it chains up to a trusted anchor.
What do we mean by _"more sophisticated"_?

Yes. Very much agreed.

Would be good to add text explaining this -- that an endorsement might contain a root certificate or other key material that is needed to establish trust in the attester 

(and it would help get closer to my prediction that 3 pages were needed :-) )
Some new DAA crypto protocol.
awesome, should we add it as an example?

```suggestion
the bottom-most (a leaf) Attesting Environment in an Attester will sign claims about one or more Target Environments
```

```suggestion
the resulting Evidence with a public key it possesses, called a verification key below. While this is typical,
```
This sentence needs healing.

Sorry, I missed the change of title.
I think this "endorsing identity" is a valid and useful conceptualisation.
What we are talking about here is precisely the endorsements that allow a verifier to know that a certain cryptographic key "speaks for" a known and genuine attester, i.e., the mechanism through which its identity is anchored.
why leaf?
I think the changed title is better since "Endorsing Identity" doesn't seem right when DAA is used but the new title and the text in the section still applies in that case.
Yeah I don't get that either
I was thinking an example of "more sophistocated" would be a certificate.

```suggestion
the bottom-most Attesting Environment in an Attester will sign claims about one or more Target Environments
```
IIUC, the DAA Issuer endorses a _group_ identity, but an identity still.

I'll give it a try:

```suggestion
of the Attester. The verification key could be, typically, a symmetric key, a raw public key, or a certified public key.
```
The rest of the WG pushed back against the concept of "identity" per se being the focus.  Is there a technical objection to the change in section title?
Can you elaborate on what the problem is?

If you are referring to the conversation starting at https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/hEnwNxvLHcLV7CQGmwQvYwztGqI/ 
there was some initial pushback from Henk and Laurence (Ned's points were more neutral), to which I replied to clarify my point further.
The conversation stopped there. So, from my perspective, it's still in limbo.

@laurencelundblade, @henkbirkholz can you please look at that thread again and see if my reply clarifies your initial confusion?
Updated text.  Is the new text better?

hmm, providing the verification key material in the form of a certificate doesn't seem to solve the scalabilty problem, it's still 1:1 with the attesters' population.

If you have the right trust anchor configured, the endorsement consists of the intermediates' certs that allow completing the path to the Attester's cert, i.e.:

```
TA -> iCA1 -> ... -> iCAn -> attesters' certs
      '-----------------'
          endorsement
```
Note that this kind of endorsement could be inlined with Evidence, e.g., in EAT (or other CWT-/JWT-based formats) using an `x5chain` header parameter.
Scalability is solved by not storing the attester's certificate.  It still comes in an endorsement, but whether that is resolved on demand or passed along with the evidence depends on the protocol.

> Scalability is solved by not storing the attester's certificate.

OK, then I don't understand what _"Attester's verification key material"_ means in the following:

> _"[e]ndorsement from an Endorser includes the Attester's verification key material in the form of a certificate that chains up to that trusted root."_

Does that exclude the leaf cert?

A certificate that includes the Attester's public key, signed by the Endorser.  I'd call that the leaf cert.  I'm saying the leaf cert need not be stored by the Verifier.  Thus the Verifier's persistent state need not be O(Attesters).

> I'm saying the leaf cert need not be stored by the Verifier. Thus the Verifier's persistent state need not be O(Attesters).

That's the key point, but lines 217-218 are not making that entirely transparent. I suggest we explicitly state it.
Ok, added sentence, please check.
Thanks very much.

```suggestion
A Verifier receives Evidence from an Attester that must be considered untrusted
until its roots of trust endorsements and their corresponding identity documents are verified through cryptography. Typically,
```
I disagree with this wording as phrased because it incorrectly implies that endorsements are mandatory.  They're not mandatory (at the expense of scalability), as other text already explains.

```suggestion
A Verifier receives Evidence from an Attesting Environment of an Attester that must be considered untrusted
```
Sorry, I read from the top down to this Section and am unsure which other text you refer to. Could you point me to the right place, please?

I checked. And then got caught up in other things. Continuing...

Appraisal of Evidence is always cut into two pieces:
1.) appraisal of Evidence provenance (most prominently signature checking in object security and peer authentication in secure channels) that identifies an Attesting Environment.
2.) appraisal of Evidence Claims that identifies or classifies a Target Environment AND are ultimately used to assess the trustworthiness that Target Environment.

So, the Attesting Environment is either endorsed or it was a Target Environment before and it was assessed to be trustworthy and now takes on the duty of an Attesting Environment. Following that line of though, on the one hand "Endorsed Identity" intuitively says "Attesting Environment" to me.

"Key Material for Attestation" could be anything, right? Text above talks about the "trust anchor actual state scenario" where the Actual State would be a trust anchor used to verify Evidence or Endorsement. The text here is talking about Evidence and somewhat Layered Attestation now. So I do not think it is about Endorsement authenticity, but only Evidence authenticity.

Could "Key Material for Attestation" simply be renamed to "Key Material for Evidence Provision and Appraisal"? Or should we massage the text to clearly include Evidence and Endorsement Authenticity?

I read the text as a whole a few times and it seems just to be unusual English phrasing for me. The new text is pretty terse, but it seems to be good enough.

In general in this Section Attester and Attesting Environment seem to be used synonymously. Would it break the meaning of the text if we would change "Attester" to "Attesting Environments of an Attester"? See exemplary suggestion above https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/rats-endorsements/pull/18/files#r1625613299

> [...] Following that line of though, on the one hand "Endorsed Identity" intuitively says "Attesting Environment" to me.

Yes, exactly.  The section is all about endorsing the authenticity of the (bottom-most) attesting environment.
And, BTW, I am fine with it.

> "Key Material for Attestation" could be anything, right?

Yes, my main concern with the proposed new title is it's too broad.  We are talking about a pretty specific use of crypto, i.e., how the verifier uses it to assess evidence's provenance.
The relevant thing is not crypto key material per se, but how we tell the verifier what key is the one that verifies the authenticity of AE's evidence statement.

> Could "Key Material for Attestation" simply be renamed to "Key Material for Evidence Provision and Appraisal"?

I don't think that makes the point any clearer.
I like your breakdown above (provenance vs claims), and I think.a more precise title would be "Endorsing Evidence Provenance".

> Or should we massage the text to clearly include Evidence and Endorsement Authenticity?

No, please.  This section has a nice and narrow scope.  Let's not bloat it.
This hurts readability and doesn't seem to add much in terms of precision.
I agree with Thomas on this one, it's much less readable.

```suggestion
# Endorsing Evidence Provenance
```
Ok, changed to "Endorsing Evidence Provenance"

> Updated text. Is the new text better?

WFM, thanks!

pulls.title: Publish XML alongside TXT and HTML on gh-pages
pulls.author: dthaler
pulls.body:
Currently TXT and HTML versions are pushed to the gh-pages branch when a PR is merged.
This PR updates the process to also publish the XML.

pulls.title: Henk's review feedback for WGLC
pulls.author: henkbirkholz
pulls.body: a little bit late, but there are always little fires everywhere.

reviews.author: dthaler
reviews.body: This looks ok to me, please rebase and mark as ready for review

comments.body: I have never seen "tree graph".  You could say "tree" or "connected and acyclic graph".  My preference is for the latter.
I prefer the non-hyphenised version "actual state".  Besides, the term should be made consistent across the whole document.
I suggest removing the sentence _"[A]dditionally, [...] not limited"_ as it doesn't add any value to the paragraph.
There is no need to add _"key, label,"_ as they are already subsumed by "other ID".
ditto

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: This looks pretty uncontroversial to me, I'll go ahead and merge :-)
